#Text=Ken Banks
#Text=For the Australian rugby league player , see Ken Banks ( rugby league ) .
#Text=Ken Banks FRSA ( born 1966 ) is a British social entrepreneur , author , and former consultant specializing in technology and global development .
#Text=He is best known for developing FrontlineSMS , a mobile messaging platform .
#Text=Early life and education
#Text=Banks
#Text=was born in 1966 in Jersey .
#Text=He has an older brother and two younger sisters and was raised by his mother , who was an amateur naturalist . [ 6 ]
#Text=At age 14 , Banks developed an interest in computing and learned how to code . [ 7 ]
#Text=He worked on a Commodore PET and developed some early computer-aided-learning programs . [ 6 ]
#Text=Banks attended Hautlieu School and Highlands College . [ 8 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=Banks
#Text=worked at a local bank , working with Burroughs B1700 mainframe computers .
#Text=Banks studied social anthropology and development studies at the University of Sussex , graduating in 1999 . [ 9 ]
#Text=Banks worked at Cable & Wireless plc helping roll out cable television across the UK before the company sold its cable assets to NTL in 2000 .
#Text=In 2001 , Banks worked as a project manager at CERCOPAN , a primate sanctuary in Nigeria .
#Text=He suffered a broken leg in a bike accident in Calabar in September 2002 and was forced to return to Jersey to recover . [ 10 ]

#Text=In December 2002 , he began working on one of the earliest mobiles for development initiatives with Fauna and Flora International ( FFI ) , a global conservation organisation based in Cambridge , UK . [ 11 ]

#Text=His work resulted in the launch of the wildlive ! mobile portal in December 2003 , [ 12 ] [ 13 ] which provided images , animal sounds , conservation-themed games , and live news to subscribers . [ 14 ]
#Text=In 2003 , he established kiwanja.net , an NGO focused on applying mobile technology for social and environmental change in the developing world , especially in Africa . [ 15 ] [ 16 ] [ 17 ]

#Text=In a special report on the use of mobile phones in development , World Watch Magazine described Banks as " probably the world 's leading voice in promoting mobile phones as an appropriate technology " . [ 18 ]
#Text=FrontlineSMS
#Text=Main article :
#Text=FrontlineSMS
#Text=Ken Banks carries out a demo of FrontlineSMS ( 2009 )

#Text=In 2004 , Banks was approached by Kruger National Park ( South Africa ) officials asking for a solution to update Bushbuckridge community members on changes and developments in the park using their mobile phones . [ 19 ] [ 20 ]
#Text=After research , it turned out that all solutions at the time required Internet access , which was n't available in the region at the time . [ 14 ]

#Text=In early 2005 , Banks realized that a simple piece of software could be developed to send and receive multiple text messages ( SMS ) to and from mobile phones using a laptop with no Internet connection . [ 21 ]
#Text=With an initial investment of 10,000 pounds , [ 14 ] [ 22 ] )
#Text=Banks started to develop FrontlineSMS in summer 2005 and completed it within 5 weeks . [ 14 ]
#Text=The software was officially launched in October 2005 .

#Text=As a result of this early work , he was invited to Stanford University as a Visiting Fellow on the Reuters Digital Vision Program in 2006 , mentoring and supporting other social entrepreneurs working on technology-driven social change initiatives . [ 23 ]

#Text=Almost two years after its launch , FrontlineSMS was used by a Nigerian organization called Humanitarian Emancipation Lead Project ( HELP ) to assist Nigerians in reporting on their 2007 national elections . [ 24 ]
#Text=The BBC ran a story , Texts monitor Nigerian elections , mentioning FrontlineSMS [ 25 ] and user downloads and global interest accelerated .
#Text=Shortly after , Banks received his first grant from the MacArthur Foundation [ 26 ] and stayed in Silicon Valley for an additional year developing the software and teaching at Stanford .
#Text=Banks later received further funding from the Hewlett Foundation , Open Society Initiative , Rockefeller Foundation and Omidyar Network . [ 22 ]
#Text=In 2009 , Banks started a two-year FrontlineSMS Ambassadors Programme with the Clinton Foundation . [ 27 ]

#Text=His work led to several awards including The Tech Awards ( 2009 ) , [ 5 ] The Antonio Pizzigati Prize for Software in the Public Interest ( 2011 ) [ 28 ] and the Curry Stone Design Prize ( 2011 ) . [ 29 ]

#Text=His work was recognised through a PopTech Social Innovation Fellowship ( September 2008 ) , [ 30 ] National Geographic Emerging Explorer ( May 2010 ) , [ 31 ] Ashoka Fellowship ( 2010 ) [ 32 ] and Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts ( 2012 ) . [ 33 ] [ 34 ]
#Text=In 2011 , Banks was invited to join the UK Prime Minister ’s delegation to Africa . [ 35 ]
#Text=In March 2012 , Banks won the Cambridge News Business Excellence Award due to a special " Corporate & Social Responsibility " nomination . [ 36 ]

column1: #Text=Later that year he launched a new startup , Means of Exchange , which focused on using technology to rebuild local communities . [ 36 ] [ 37 ]
#Text=One of the project ’s first initiatives was a " cash mob " during the London Olympics . [ 38 ]
#Text=In May 2012 , Banks announced a management change at FrontlineSMS .
#Text=Laura Walker Hudson took over the running of The kiwanja Foundation ( which later became SIMLab ) and Sean McDonald took over the running of FrontlineSMS .
#Text=Banks took on a new role as Chair of the Board . [ 39 ]
#Text=After FrontlineSMS
#Text=Ken Banks presenting his Means of Exchange initiative at PopTech in 2012
#Text=In 2015 , Banks became the first entrepreneur in residence at CARE International , [ 40 ] [ 41 ] and took the position of Visiting Fellow at RMIT University ( Melbourne ) . [ 42 ]
#Text=In 2016 , Banks received the ACM Eugene L. Lawler Award for Humanitarian Contributions within Computer Science ( 2016 ) for his work with mobile technology and community empowerment . [ 3 ]

#Text=In March 2018 , Banks was appointed Visiting Fellow at Cambridge Judge Business School [ 43 ] and in April 2018 he closed down his consultancy , kiwanja.net , and took on a full-time role at digital identity startup Yoti as their Head of Social Purpose . [ 44 ]
#Text=Publications
#Text=Banks has written for WIRED Magazine , The Guardian , the BBC , and the Stanford Social Innovation Review , among others .
#Text=Banks ' first edited book , The Rise of the Reluctant Innovator , was self-published in late 2013 and came with a foreword from Archbishop Desmond Tutu . [ 45 ]

#Text=His second book , Social Entrepreneurship and Innovation , was published by Kogan Page and released in March 2016 with forewords by British musician Peter Gabriel and the founder of Ashoka , Bill Drayton . [ 46 ]
#Text=Awards and fellowships
